replies.author: @fred1barb
replies.text:
@RolandSRodriguez You need to read the entire Article 3 and Federalist 43 to understand the meaning and intent of the founders. There are some court decisions that explicate and expand the interpretation somewhat and the decision summaries are worth a read.  The first clause is a necessary condition "Treason ... shall consist only in levying War against them, or in adhering to their Enemies, giving them Aid and Comfort." The founders intended the clause to be construed narrowly to guard against "new-fangled and artificial treasons" (Madison- Miscellaneous Powers No. 3, Federalist 43.)

18 U.S. Code ¬ß 1031 - Major fraud against the United States appears to be the appropriate law and it provides very heavy penalties. Fines up to $10,000,000 etc.

replies.author: @RolandSRodriguez
replies.text: ‚Äã@fred1barb You need to provide a definition of Enemies that excludes people stealing tax funds.

replies.author: @fred1barb
replies.text: @megamax898 Some Somalis might be doing that, or all Somalis might be doing that. It can be charged as a crime as "Providing Material Support To Designated Terrorist Organizations (Fundraising) (18 U.S.C. 2339B)" and perhaps some other sections. But that is not treason against the United States. Treason is defined in the constitution, and it essentially means to levy war on the US or to give aid and comfort in time of war. The Supreme Court has expanded on this slightly, but the essence remains the same. Only 13 people have been convicted of treason since the constitution was ratified.

replies.author: @fred1barb
replies.text:
@RolandSRodriguez Enemies has to be read in context. It does not mean hostile, unfriendly or opposed and it does not mean a political enemy. 
The text starts with making war against the US, which gives us the meaning of enemy as the opponent in a war.

 Foreign governments and armies cannot commit treason, only persons subject to the authority of the US can commit treason.  

Treason is war against the US or adhering to those who make war against the US "giving them aid and comfort.

The court has given some deference to the Congress in interpreting these provisions gradually moving away from a narrow requirement of actual hostilities and recognizing the rise of non-state actors as the hostile party. 

Even so enemy is still seen in the context of a war or warlike action. For these Somalis to be guilty of treason Al-Shabaab would need to be in fact an enemy of US in the sense of an active armed threat to the US not to Somalia, and the Somalis would have to be shown to have loyalty to Al-Shabaab. Sending money to Somalia would not be sufficient proof. You would have to show that each person knew the money was going to Al-Shabaab and that they knew Al-Shabaab was an enemy of the US.  Al-Shabaab is on an administrative terrorist organization list but for criminal prosecution it could well be that you would have to show that it is actively in support of or engaged in hostile action against the US.

replies.author: @fred1barb
replies.text:
@8Rider6 The elements of treason and the proof required are set in the Constitution. The wording is so strict that only 13 people have ever been convicted of treason. The aid and comfort clause is not a free standing crime. There has been some interpretation by the courts, but SCOTUS has not yet made aid and comfort in and of itself a crime and enemies does not mean whomever the DOJ calls an enemy.  You may recall the old Attorney General's list of subversive organizations, an enemies list if ever there was one. No one was ever charged with treason for membership and membership without some criminal act or conspiracy to commit a crime cannot be itself a crime because of the 1st Amendment.

Defrauding the US is a crime under 18USC but it is not treason.
